clues: This city has a famous clock tower known as Big Ben.
Home to the royal family and Buckingham Palace.
fun_fact: London has over 170 museums, including the British Museum, which is free to visit!
The London Underground, also called 'The Tube,' is the oldest subway system in the world.
trivia: The London Eye attracts over 3 million visitors every year.
More than 300 languages are spoken in London, making it one of the most linguistically diverse cities in the world.

clues: Famous for its Opera House and Harbour Bridge.
This city hosted the 2000 Summer Olympics.
fun_fact: Sydney has over 100 beaches along its coastline.
The Sydney Harbour Bridge is also known as 'The Coathanger' due to its shape.
trivia: Bondi Beach is one of the most famous beaches in the world.
Sydney's Taronga Zoo is home to over 4,000 animals.

clues: This city was once divided by a famous wall.
Known for its vibrant art and techno music scene.
fun_fact: Berlin has more bridges than Venice!
The Berlin Wall fell in 1989, marking the end of the Cold War.
trivia: The city has one of the largest train stations in Europe.
Berlin’s public transportation system operates 24/7 on weekends.

clues: Home to the world's tallest building.
Known for its luxurious shopping and man-made islands.
fun_fact: Dubai has no permanent rivers.
The Burj Khalifa is so tall that residents on upper floors see the sunset later than those on lower floors.
trivia: Dubai Mall is one of the largest shopping malls in the world.
Dubai’s police force uses supercars like Lamborghinis and Ferraris.

clues: Home to an ancient amphitheater where gladiators once fought.
The Vatican City, the smallest country in the world, is located here.
fun_fact: Ancient Romans used to clean their clothes with urine because of its ammonia content!
Rome has more fountains than any other city in the world.
trivia: The Colosseum could hold up to 50,000 spectators.
The city was founded in 753 BC according to legend.

clues: Home to one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
The longest river in the world flows through this city.
fun_fact: Cairo is known as 'The City of a Thousand Minarets' due to its numerous mosques.
The Pyramids of Giza are over 4,500 years old.
trivia: The Great Sphinx of Giza is missing its nose.
Cairo has the oldest and largest film and music industry in the Arab world.

clues: This city is famous for its colorful, onion-shaped domes.
The capital of the largest country in the world.
fun_fact: Moscow’s metro stations are known as ‘underground palaces’ due to their ornate design.
The Kremlin houses the largest bell in the world, the Tsar Bell.
trivia: Red Square is not actually named after its color but from an old Russian word meaning ‘beautiful’.
Moscow has more billionaires than any other city in Europe.

clues: This city is the only one in the world that spans two continents.
Once known as Constantinople, it was the capital of the Byzantine Empire.
fun_fact: Istanbul has over 3,000 mosques, including the famous Blue Mosque.
It was once the capital of three different empires: Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman.
trivia: The city’s Grand Bazaar is one of the largest and oldest covered markets in the world.
Istanbul’s Hagia Sophia has served as a church, mosque, and now a museum.

clues: Home to one of the tallest free-standing towers in the world.
This city is often mistaken as the capital of its country.
fun_fact: Toronto is one of the most multicultural cities in the world, with over 140 languages spoken.
It has an underground city called PATH, which connects various downtown buildings.
trivia: The CN Tower was the tallest free-standing structure in the world until 2007.
Toronto’s Yonge Street was once considered the longest street in the world.

clues: This city’s full ceremonial name has over 169 characters.
Famous for its floating markets and vibrant street food scene.
fun_fact: Bangkok’s official name is the longest city name in the world.
It is home to the world’s largest golden Buddha statue.
trivia: Bangkok is the most visited city in the world.
The city has over 400 Buddhist temples.

clues: Famous for its Christ the Redeemer statue.
Hosts one of the biggest carnival celebrations in the world.
fun_fact: Rio de Janeiro means ‘River of January’ in Portuguese.
The city’s beaches, including Copacabana, are world-famous.
trivia: Rio was the capital of Brazil until 1960.
Sugarloaf Mountain offers stunning views of the city.

clues: Home to the iconic Table Mountain.
This city is known for its stunning coastal scenery and vineyards.
fun_fact: Cape Town was the first city in Africa to host the FIFA World Cup.
It has the oldest colonial building in South Africa, the Castle of Good Hope.
trivia: The city’s Cape of Good Hope is not the southernmost point of Africa.
Cape Town has one of the highest biodiversity levels in the world.

clues: Home to the world’s largest film industry by production volume.
This city was formerly known as Bombay.
fun_fact: Mumbai’s local trains carry over 7 million passengers daily.
The Gateway of India was built to welcome King George V and Queen Mary in 1911.
trivia: Mumbai is built on a series of seven islands.
It is home to one of the world’s most expensive private residences, Antilia.

clues: Famous for its massive Christ the Redeemer statue.
This city hosts one of the world's biggest carnival festivals.
fun_fact: The city's name means 'River of January' in Portuguese.
Rio’s beaches, like Copacabana and Ipanema, are world-famous.
trivia: The Maracanã stadium once held the largest attendance for a World Cup final.
Sugarloaf Mountain offers one of the best views of the city.

clues: This city has one of the most recognizable towers in the world.
Often mistaken as the capital of its country, but it’s not!
fun_fact: Toronto’s PATH system is the world's largest underground shopping complex.
Over half of Toronto’s residents are born outside Canada.
trivia: Toronto is home to the tallest free-standing structure in the Western Hemisphere.
The Toronto Raptors won their first NBA championship in 2019.

clues: This city is home to the stunning Table Mountain.
Known for its colorful houses in the Bo-Kaap neighborhood.
fun_fact: Cape Town was the first city outside Europe to have street lights.
The city has a colony of penguins at Boulders Beach!
trivia: It was the first city in South Africa to be colonized by Europeans.
Robben Island, where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned, is located here.

clues: The capital of its country, known for street food and motorbikes.
Famous for its historic Old Quarter and Hoan Kiem Lake.
fun_fact: Hanoi is over 1,000 years old and was once called Thang Long.
Egg coffee was invented in this city due to a milk shortage.
trivia: The city has a railway that runs right through a residential street.
It was once the capital of French Indochina.

clues: One of the world’s oldest cities, known for ancient ruins.
Home to the Acropolis and Parthenon.
fun_fact: The Olympic Games were revived here in 1896.
Athens has more theaters than any other city in the world!
trivia: The Greek capital is named after the goddess of wisdom.
Democracy was born in this city over 2,500 years ago.

clues: This city awards the Nobel Peace Prize every year.
Surrounded by fjords and forests, it's one of the greenest capitals.
fun_fact: Oslo has a Viking Ship Museum showcasing well-preserved Viking ships.
Norway’s royal family lives in the Oslo Royal Palace.
trivia: The city was previously known as Christiania.
Oslo is one of the most expensive cities in the world to live in.

clues: Previously known as Calcutta, it was once the capital of British India.
Famous for its grand colonial architecture and Durga Puja festival.
fun_fact: The city is home to the world’s oldest polo club.
Kolkata’s Howrah Bridge is one of the busiest cantilever bridges in the world.
trivia: This city was the birthplace of Nobel laureate Rabindranath Tagore.
Known as the ‘Cultural Capital of India’.

clues: Known as the 'City of a Hundred Spires.'
The Charles Bridge and Prague Castle are major attractions.
fun_fact: Prague's Astronomical Clock is over 600 years old and still working!
Beer is cheaper than water in many restaurants here.
trivia: The famous writer Franz Kafka was born in this city.
The city was left mostly untouched during World War II.

clues: Home to the largest Gothic cathedral in the world.
Famous for flamenco dancing and its historic Alcázar palace.
fun_fact: Seville is known for its oranges, but the bitter fruit is mostly used for marmalade.
Christopher Columbus is buried in Seville Cathedral.
trivia: The annual Feria de Abril is one of Spain’s most colorful festivals.
The city was once a major center for trade with the New World.

clues: The capital of one of the richest countries in the world.
Home to the futuristic skyline and the Museum of Islamic Art.
fun_fact: Doha was largely a pearl diving and fishing village before oil wealth transformed it.
Qatar has no forests—the only country in the world without them.
trivia: Doha hosted the FIFA World Cup in 2022.
The city has a traditional market called Souq Waqif, famous for spices and falcons.
